There are multiple official declarations that confirm that the subject of sanctioning or coercing Turkey in one way or another will be debated in the next EU council in December, but it does not confirm that the question of an Arms Embargo (which requires a vote by unanimity) is going to be discussed.
The EU is very capable of applying arms embargoes— it's actually the case for 7 countries (18 if we count the UN sanctions that are followed by the EU)— but the EU's official policy is to favor diplomatic dialogue, in general. There are also a large variety of other sanctions that can be used instead.
Greece, which is the main concerned country is not 100% supporting an embargo, because, as Hungary and Malta, it fears the threat of an immigration flow that Turkey could release in retaliation. Germany, Spain, and Italy have economic interests that may affect their desire to apply an arms embargo. All those countries opposed their veto to a proposition of an arms embargo in 2019. However, the situation is much different in 2020 and has escalated. Since Turkey is rejecting dialogue and, on the contrary, increases its threats, the tension escalates on both sides. I believe only Hungary and Malta may be opposed to an embargo now. The stronger will of the other EU countries may force them to oblige, provided that concessions are made or actions are taken to deal with the migration problems.
The recent waves of terrorism attacks (though not directly related to migration) have given more incentives to seriously address the migration issue (I heard some official declarations on the subject which pointed to an EU consensus). It will very likely be debated in December. Therefore, there's a possibility that Hungary and Malta agree on the arms embargo if their concerns regarding migration are tackled simultaneously through another set of decisions and actions.
As far as other countries (external to the EU) are concerned, I see no potential pressure that could prevent the EU from taking sanctions. EU sanctions do not apply to non-EU countries, and, in particular, the US and the UK (who are both selling arms to Turkey) would not be affected. However, this simple fact may also discourage the EU to apply any sanctions that may then be ineffective (as Turkey claims they would), especially if Russia keeps trading arms with Turkey too. Moreover, it is true that Turkey has a growing military industry that is more and more able to sustain Turkey's needs (at least for short term needs).
Therefore, I estimate a 90% chances that sanctions will be discussed in December. 80% chances the question of Arms embargo will be discussed in that case (thus 72% overall). 50% chances it will be put to a vote (=> 36%). 70% chances it will be a unanimous yes, if voted.
Hence, I get a 25% overall (I have multiplied all those percentages). Note: I consider that members of the council will have a good idea of the outcome of the vote prior it, but they may still feel voting is a useful strategic move to threaten Turkey (as they probably did in 2019). Turkey is part of NATO but it is a separate organization and it seems that it would not have an impact on this EU decision. Some NATO countries have already applied some sanctions toward Turkey (the US for instance, regarding the F-35 sales).
As a NATO nation, I don't think this is the most likely method for the EU to respond to 'undesirable' actions.
